none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from John James, June 27, 1890
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from John James, June 27, 1890
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

For Stock in Choice North Texas National Banks, $100 to $5,000,
10 per cent. net per annum guaranteed; Vendors liens,
Commercial Paper, Collateral Loans, 10 per
cent.; Five year 8 per cent. First Mortgages;
or Texas County Bonds, address

Farmers National Bank, Henrietta, Tex.
CAPITAL, $50,000.
JOHN G. JAMES, Pres't,
A. K. SWAN, V.-Pres't,
F. B. WYATT, Cashier.

JOHN G. JAMES,
HENRIETTA, TEXAS.

First National Bank, Quanah, Tex.
CAPITAL, $50,000.
JOHN G. JAMES, Pres't,
W. E. JOHNSON, V.-Pres't,
H. M. VICTOR, Cashier.

MAPS, CIRCULARS and NEWSPA-
PERS of this Section Mailed
Free.

[Body]

Henrietta Tex June 27/90

Prof. L. L. McInnis,
College Station Tex.

Dear McInnis: Have been called away or would have
written sooner. Am greatly astonished at the news of
your last letter, & cant imagine what influence caused
the trouble. Had supposed you were safely fixed for life, or as
long as you chose to stay. But really it may be a
blessing in disguise. Your business capacity once fairly
directed in some other channel, will pay you better, &
leave you a free man. The position was one very distasteful
to me, as you recollect, & I left it as soon as I could.
You get no thanks, & the more you do, the more stabs, &
kicks & abuse you get from those who ought to commend
& support you.

You will have the summer to look around in, & decide what is
best. If a point to suit you can be found, I would suggest a
private bank - you could do really a nice business on your
capital, & be free to handle vendor-liens & other real Estate
paper, not legal for Nat Banks. But real Estate is the one
great profitable business now. With shrewdness & judgment, &
good knowledge of lands, care in titles, &c, there will be more
money made in that line in next five years in Texas, than

**Transcription Analysis Complete** Alright, let's see what we've got here. My task is to transcribe this letter, paying close attention to every detail, including the original formatting and any peculiarities in the handwriting. The document starts with a printed header, a real estate pitch, and I'll lay that out first. The writer is John G. James, and he's quite the businessman, judging by the advertisements and his positions at two national banks in Texas. He's clearly trying to drum up some business for vendors' liens, commercial paper, and real estate investments. Then comes the handwritten letter itself, addressed to a Professor McInnis at College Station. Here's my transcription: [Header] For Stock in Choice North Texas National Banks, $100 to $5,000,
10 per cent. net per annum guaranteed; Vendors liens,
Commercial Paper, Collateral Loans, 10 per cent.;
Five year 8 per cent. First Mortgages;
or Texas County Bonds, address Farmers National Bank, Henrietta, Tex.
CAPITAL, $50,000.
JOHN G. JAMES, Pres't,
A. K. SWAN, V.-Pres't,
F. B. WYATT, Cashier. JOHN G. JAMES,
HENRIETTA, TEXAS. First National Bank, Quanah, Tex.
CAPITAL, $50,000.
JOHN G. JAMES, Pres't,
W. E. JOHNSON, V.-Pres't,
H. M. VICTOR, Cashier. MAPS, CIRCULARS and NEWSPAPERS of this Section Mailed Free. [Body] Henrietta Tex June 27/90 Prof. L. L. McInnis, College Station Tex. Dear McInnis: Have been called away or would have written sooner. Am greatly astonished at the news of your last letter, & cant imagine what influence caused the trouble. Had supposed you were safely fixed for life, or as long as you chose to stay. But really it may be a blessing in disguise. Your business capacity once fairly directed in some other channel, will pay you better, & leave you a free man. The position was one very distasteful to me, as you recollect, & I left it as soon as I could. You get no thanks, & the more you do, the more stabs, & kicks & abuse you get from those who ought to commend & support you. You will have the summer to look around in, & decide what is best. If a point to suit you can be found, I would suggest a private bank - You could do really a nice business on your capital, & be free to handle vendor-liens & other real Estate paper, not legal for Nat Banks. But real Estate is the one great profitable business now. With shrewdness & judgment, & good knowledge of lands, care in titles, &c, there will be more money made in that line in next five years in Texas, than

[Header]

[1890, June 27]

Farmers National Bank, Henrietta, Tex.
CAPITAL, $50.000.
JOHN G. JAMES, Pres't,
A. K. SWAN, V.-Pres't,
F. B. WYATT, Cashier.

For Stock in Choice North Texas National Banks, $100 to $5,000,
10 per cent. net per annum guaranteed; Vendors liens,
Commercial Paper, Collateral Loans, 10 per
cent.; Five year 8 per cent. First Mortgages;
or Texas County Bonds, address
JOHN G. JAMES,
HENRIETTA, TEXAS.

[Margin: MAPS, CIRCULARS and NEWSPA-
PERS of this Section Mailed
Free.]

First National Bank, Quanah, Tex,
CAPITAL, $50,000.
JOHN G. JAMES, Pres't,
W. E. JOHNSON, V.-Pres't,
H. M. VICTOR, Cashier.

[/Header]

in anything else, and the way real estate is moving now, a
good trader can turn his money over frequently in a year.
Not only is there a great boom all over this North West
country, but I learn it is even greater in South Western
Texas. Study the situation, & see what field is best. If I
were free from the Banks, & the great responsibility they impose,
I would confine my attention to real estate, until values
here became equalized, & the boom over.
I will gladly do all I can to help you, & will advise
you freely & carefully, but your own good judgment & business
tastes are best guide. I could help you start a private business
at good point near here, and after learning the details, could
assist you in making a Natl, if afterwards desirable. But
from all I hear now the greatest development promises to be
on the Coast or in S. W. Texas, & you should carefully
consider that field. I am so tied down I cannot leave
to visit it. Give me full particulars of the trouble at the
College. If you come up in this section be sure to come &
see me. My best services are at your command when
you desire to perfect your arrangements.
With best regards         Very truly Yrs

Jno G. James.

**Here's how I approached this transcription, step by step.** Initially, I recognized my role as a transcriptionist and understood the task at hand: to accurately reproduce the text from a handwritten letter within the specified formatting constraints, paying close attention to the original spelling and punctuation, and carefully interpreting the handwriting. I then began by dissecting the image. I started with a systematic analysis of the letterhead, meticulously transcribing each block of text and noting the visual layout, attempting to reproduce it linearly because the prompt limits to available HTML tags. I carefully examined the cursive handwriting, line by line, to ensure precise transcription, paying extra attention to potentially ambiguous words. I made a special note of the date at the top and the signature.

I then started to prepare the formatting, noting that I was limited to specific HTML tags, which meant I had to creatively adapt to represent the intended visual arrangement. I analyzed the layout and decided to transcribe the header items top-to-bottom, left-to-right.

Next, I worked through a refined transcription process. I started by checking the date, then the various blocks of header text, and then the body of the letter, attempting to read the handwriting, line by line. I focused on potentially difficult words and contextual clues. I decided to make my own corrections and refinements during this phase. I made a critical assessment of the word "Natl" and considered every alternative before concluding it was correct. I took pains to analyze the ink blot and determine the word as "do". I also carefully considered the spelling of "busines" and similar phrases.

The final stage involved polishing the text, double-checking for punctuation, and refining formatting choices, particularly with the header layout. I made key decisions about how to best represent the header elements given the HTML limitations. I performed final checks of the overall text and double-checked key decisions. I reviewed the context of the letter, the location of the banks, and the handwriting carefully. Then, I prepared the text for the final output, carefully structuring each part of the letter: date, header blocks, body text, and signature. I've attempted to replicate the letter as accurately as possible within the constraints, and this is what I've provided.
